comments.text:
They have special extra long sticks which they hold out the window and 
sweep in front of their car. Then they just drive and stop when they hit 
something. They orient themselves by hearing at nearby claxons and screams, 
hitting sidewalks or poles (either with the stick or with the car) and 
their cars make a special clicking sound every 10 yards so they can tell 
distance.

You should see them try parallel parking, it's hilarious.
comments.author: Lukas don

comments.text: They obviously can't see the road lol so they really don't.

top_comment.text:
Could you imagine to be deaf? I mean I think you wish to see but would you 
give up sound for seight?﻿
top_comment.author: SeloPeylo

comments.text:
+angry grunt
What a question, blind people, at least in western world, have a good life 
and are happy with it, many also have jobs and even if not they can still 
enjoy the same as the rest of us, like cold beer, good music, radio, they 
can even read (braille), or listen to audio books. Sure blind is worse than 
deaf but being blind isnt the end of life, far from it. You should watch 
more of Edisons videos, really.
comments.author: Ploffy Kha

comments.text:
what would be worse being blind or being in vegetable state( you cant move 
anything in your body except your eyes)
comments.author: angry grunt

comments.text:
My favorite girl friend is deaf and she have no problems worth mentioning. 
She can hear deep tones of loud music and could [most likely] simply have 
used a hearing aid to be able to hear like 70-80% of what other people say 
but she dont like, so we can safely say its by her own choosing. And shes 
also mute, that too is by choice, she can sometimes talk when shes angry or 
upset, though hard to understand anything at all of what she say so its 
really insignificant. Bottom line is she dont feel she have a handicap and 
i never thought of her as handicapped as well. A happy, fun and very 
charming young lady.
comments.author: Ploffy Kha

comments.text:
+The Fox Not the most dominant, but humans are primarily visual creatures. 
Dogs have more powerful noses than we do, and bats have significantly 
improved hearing than we do, but we have far superior sight to both bats 
and dogs.
comments.author: AGiantPie

comments.text:
+Sizzlik Well, they DO say that sight is the most dominant sense of the 
five senses.
comments.author: Flippy

comments.text:
if i had to choose i would would choose sight over hearing. But thats 
really a hard question..like would you rather give one arm or one leg? No 
hearing..no music, imense sounds of waves clashing on the beach..birds 
tweeding..thunder storms. No sight..never know what humans look like..never 
see a sun rise/set..beauty of nature..
comments.author: Sizzlik

top_comment.text:
A less child-oriented version of the Quick Talker would be helpful for my 
partner, who is autistic and sometimes becomes frustrated at being unable 
to verbally express urgent needs. I think the appearance of the tool, which 
looks something like a toy, would make it a little humiliating for adults 
to use.

We both get frustrated that society in general seems to assume that autism 
is a condition that only exists in children. It's not like you grow out of 
it, after all.

Still, it's a very cool idea and I really like that there's a way for 
people with disabilities to meet and discover clever tools like that.﻿
top_comment.author: Pixel Smith

comments.text:
There are similar tools for adults, and older children, with far more 
pre-programmed phrases. That's more of an early learner's tool for a young 
child. 

I like +gomika's suggestion. Switching to writing might also be easier for 
your partner once they become nonverbal. Good luck to you both! :)
comments.author: ThePurpleSeahorse

comments.text:
Its because it looks so big and clunky. A more modern alternative could be 
recording audio notes on a smart phone and making shortcuts to each one for 
easy access!

comments.author: lairdbearly

comments.text:
+CoTeCiOtm i mean, I'm pretty sure he has a pretty basic understanding of 
the concept of written language, even though he can't see it. He can read 
braille, and even has a video of himself writing letters with a pen and 
paper.
comments.author: Brandon Melling

comments.text:
+CoTeCiOtm Look my sister is blind, I grew up with foster children who were 
severely handicapped and have some physical limitations myself. That is to 
say I know a thing or two about it. Trust me just because someone is blind 
does not mean they are incapable of grasping a concept. Also no, I don't 
have to admit any thing of the sort.The analogy was fine. How do I know 
this? Because my sister understands it perfectly even though she has 
prosthetic eyes.
comments.author: hyperthermogenic

comments.text:
It's not "that" hard. It's simply braille for sighted people. I mean he 
can't imagine seeing exactly, but understands the concept of subtitles.
comments.author: NoNamer123456789

comments.text:
Yeah, I'm pretty sure he is, as he is familiar with many other concepts 
that he can't see which he adresses on his other videos, but you still got 
to admit that the captioned TV thing was a terrible analogy to tell a blind 
person. You can see that when Tommy says "Sure" in a way like he's thinking 
"I got no idea what you mean, but whatever"
comments.author: CoTeCiOtm

comments.text: He is blind not stupid.
comments.author: hyperthermogenic

comments.text: im sure he's familiar with the concept
comments.author: rox

top_comment.text:
There is also an iPhone app called "Be My Eyes." that visually impaired 
people can hook up with a seeing people to get help using the phones 
camera. Check it out at http://bemyeyes.org/  it's pretty cool.﻿
top_comment.author: Alex Smith

comments.text:
+FalconFetus8
actually, blind people would be able to use iPhones because there's an 
accessibility option on the phone; there's one called VoiceOver for blind 
people. All the blind people I know (only a few) say that iPhone is the 
most accessible phone out there. The problem is not the phone, (though 
there's room for improvement) but the apps and websites that are not 
accessible. Now, I've no knowledge of what the app Alex Smith is 
mentioning, but considering it is for visually-impaired people, it would be 
accessible. What's nice is that there are apps that aren't specially meant 
to cater to blind people, but are accessible nonetheless. An example is the 
song finding app "Shazam" vs "Soundhound". I use Soundhound because I was 
introduced to it by my brother, but one of my blind friend uses Shazam. I 
asked why she doesn't use Soundhound and she says that Shazam is more 
accessible.
comments.author: Temporal Catcher

comments.text:
I'd imagine that would be hard for a blind person to use, though.  They 
would have no idea where on the screen they're touching, and it's not like 
smart phones have buttons anymore.
comments.author: FalconFetus8

comments.text:
+Trenton Cottrell Don't be silly. The lady herself said that you can record 
any applicable message.
comments.author: Micheal Johnson

comments.text:
a person who can't speak and has that thing to communicate will eat a whole 
bunch of bananas
comments.author: Trenton Cottrell

comments.text: lol

captions.text:
(Robot) Put your hand on the side of my head again.
(Tommy) Okay.
We've only just met. (gasp)
Oooh. Hey. Hi everybody.
(music)
I'm at the International Technology and Persons with Disabilities Conference
in San Diego. And today, I want to show you some of the brand new
things that are available for folks with all sorts of disabilities.
(music resolves)
(Tommy) This is Jarek and he's from a company called Harpo. How are you doing today?

(Jarek) Very good. How are you?
(Tommy) I'm great. Thank you so much.
So what are you demoing today? What do you have here at the conference?
(Jarek) We have a bunch of devices for blind people. One of which
is the P.I.A.F. It's Pictures In A Flash.

(Tommy) Ooh!
(Jarek) It's a really cool device that helps
kids to experience the
technographics but also have the teachers to create
technographics almost on the fly.

(Tommy) Wow. That's fantastic.
(Jarek) What you need for it is a special swell paper.

I have a sample here.
(Tommy) Okay.
(Tommy) The first thing you do
is you design the picture. Then you print it on this paper.
You just put it through the P.I.A.F.

It's really like putting a toast in the toaster.
(Tommy laughs)
(Jarek) And after a few seconds, it will come out

puffed up.
(Tommy) A raised line drawing.
(Jarek) Yes.
(Jarek) So, here is now the outcome.

Now you see all the lines are raised.
(Tommy) Yeah.

(Jarek) And it's in Braille.
(Tommy) Everything. This is incredible.
And it's like a floor plan. Look at that. Look at this.
And a teacher could just make this in class

in a second?
(Jarek) Yeah. Exactly.
(Tommy) That is genius. I love this. I wish they had this when I was in school.

I might have paid attention more.
(Jarek) Maybe you be a mathematical
wiz or something now.

(Tommy) You can tell he just met me.
(Both laugh)
(music)
(Tommy) This is Scott Larsen and he's from a company called Caption Call.
Now, tell me about this. What exactly is this? What happens?

How does it work?
(Scott) Well, this Caption Call phone
captions what the other person is saying. So if somebody has
difficulty hearing on the phone. They can both hear
and read what is being said.
(Tommy) So if I'm talking to somebody who is hearing impaired, for example,

they can read what I'm saying?
(Scott) That's exactly right.
Somebody who has this Caption Call phone in their home
they will see what you're saying on the screen.
It's kind of like your captioned television when you

turn on the captions.
(Tommy) Sure.
(Scott) You can see what the other person

is saying right on the screen.
(Tommy) You know, I think the only draw back
is that the hard of hearing have to put up with telemarketers
and people trying to sell them the newspaper and raise money and all that. You know what I mean?
The old days it was -- what, what, I can't hear you?
(music)
(Tommy) I want you to meet Kristen. She's from a company called AbleNet.
You're doing very cool stuff. What's happening? What's going on? What do you do?
(Kristen) We do switches and communication devices. And we also do
mounting and computer access for people with
physical disabilities or learning disabilities as well.
(Tommy) Wow. And what's the thing you have in your hand? How does this work?
So, this is the Quick Talker 12. So it's a portable communication device.
It's durable and it has a handle. And has you're walking around you can
record different messages and people are able to communicate
pressing different buttons and communicate with

other people using the device.
(Tommy) So this is for then non-verbal
kids, right? Kids who maybe have autism or something like that?

Or just don't speak?
(Kristen) Yeah, definitely. So, here's

the top one.
(VOX) I want more.
(Tommy) Okay. Alright. Okay. What else?

(VOX) I want to eat a banana.
(Kristen) It said I want to eat a banana.
(Tommy) Yep.

(Kristen) I love M&Ms.
(Tommy) Oh, I love
M&Ms too. Plain or peanut?
(Kristen) Well, you got to go with the peanut butter. Definitely the peanut butter.

(VOX) I need help.
(Tommy) Oh, wow.
(Kristen) Yeah.

(Kristen) Well, I have one more button for you.
(Tommy) Yes.
(VOX) I'm all done.

(Tommy) That's it? You're done. No more?
(Kristen) I'm all done.
(credits music)
(Tommy) You know what would be cool if you had a button on that said, "Get me another beer."
(Kristen) Well, we can record that for you.

(Tommy) Can you?
(Kristen) Yes. Definitely.

You can take it to the bar with you whenever you'd like.
(Tommy laughs)

title: Cool Stuff For Blind, Deaf, or Non-Verbal People
